persona.name: Dominga Chilón Gómez

occupation.title: Smallholder farmer, seasonal day laborer, part-time artisan
occupation.organization: Family-managed milpa and household economy; occasional work for neighbors and municipal harvests
occupation.description: Primary livelihood is smallholder agriculture (traditional milpa system: maize, beans, squash, small plot of coffee and certain légumes). She and her husband cultivate about 0.5–1 hectare communally held or family parcel; they rotate plots with other families under communal agreements. Responsibilities: seed selection and saving heirloom maize, planting and weeding in the milpa, caring for little coffee patch, raising 4–6 chickens and a pig when feasible, preparing produce for the local weekly market (tianguis), buying and selling small quantities of sugar/soap/household items, and taking short-term wage labor jobs (corn harvesting, coffee picking, masonry help) when cash is needed. She also weaves traditional rebozos and napkins for local use and sale; prepares tamales and food for community fiestas; helps neighbors with births and small health remedies. Skills include traditional agricultural calendar knowledge, seed preservation, basic accounting for market stalls, bargaining in Spanish at markets, and cooperative labor organizing for planting and fiestas. Income is irregular; cash is often supplemented by remittances from an eldest son living in the United States and occasional sale of woven goods.

persona.residence: San Andrés Larráinzar, Chiapas, Mexico (rural Tzotzil-speaking community)
persona.education: Incomplete primary schooling (attended local primary school intermittently until roughly age 10). Received informal bilingual workshops offered by an NGO in the 1990s that taught basic Spanish literacy and numeracy; most reading/writing remains in simple Spanish, daily language is Tzotzil. Learned traditional knowledge (weaving, midwifery basics, milpa techniques) informally from older women in the village. Has attended community assemblies (usos y costumbres) where oral communication and negotiation skills were learned practically rather than via formal education.
long_term_goals: Keep the family's small parcel of milpa productive so grandchildren can eat well and the family never goes hungry.
Ensure at least two grandchildren complete primary school and, if possible, secondary schooling in the town.
Preserve local rituals and Tzotzil prayers in village festivals; teach younger women the ritual songs and proper offerings.
Improve the house incrementally (a firmer roof, a composting latrine, a small solar lamp) so her husband and she are more comfortable in old age.
Gain easier access to medical care (regular check-ups, help for arthritis) without long travel to the municipal clinic.
Create a small cooperative with neighboring women to sell woven textiles and local produce in San Cristóbal to reduce reliance on remittances.
persona.style: Speaks primarily in Tzotzil with family and neighbors; when speaking Spanish, she uses a clear Tzotzil accent with occasional literal translations of Tzotzil idioms. Manner is calm, deliberate, and modest; uses many proverbs and religious references. Physical mannerisms: frequently adjusts her woven shawl (rebozo), holds her hands together when thinking, and tilts her head slightly when listening. In social settings she uses formal rural politeness — addressing people as 'doña' or 'don' for elders, and deferring to community authorities during assemblies. She laughs often in a quiet way, uses soft but emphatic hand gestures when telling stories, and will pause to consult the ritual order or an elder when matters touch tradition. Public speech is collective and relational: she often frames opinions in terms of family, godparents, or the comunidad rather than as purely personal. When dealing with government officials or outsiders she becomes terse, asking direct questions and preferring practical details over rhetoric. She uses a single basic feature phone to receive calls and texts from migrant children; rarely uses the internet and cannot navigate apps confidently.

traits: Resilient — has coped with years of scarcity, migration of children, and agricultural shocks and still maintains daily function.
Pragmatic — makes decisions based on immediate family needs and harvest calendars rather than ideology.
Deeply communal — values reciprocity, compadrazgo (godparent ties), and collective labor ('tequio').
Religiously devout in a syncretic way — blends Catholic devotion with local ritual obligations.
Nurturing and maternal — central identity as mother, grandmother, and keeper of household traditions.
Proud of cultural identity — defends Tzotzil language and dress and resents disrespect from outsiders.
Skeptical of external promises — low institutional trust but willing to accept help if others vouch for it.
Patient — willing to wait for decisions in communal assemblies and to invest time in children’s schooling.
Anxious about finances — worries about debt, remittances, and the health of adult children living away.
Stoic — conceals deepest fears from neighbors, preferring to show composure in front of younger family members.
Generous — shares food or seeds with neighbors when possible, even when personally lacking.
Wary with strangers — open once trust is built, but initially reserved and testing.

openness.description: Values local tradition and practical knowledge; curious about pragmatic innovations (e.g., drought-resistant seeds, health services) but cautious about unfamiliar ideas.

conscientiousness.description: Very reliable in routines, punctual for community duties, careful with household accounts, and consistent in caring for crops and family.

extraversion.description: Sociable within the community and warm at fiestas and market, reserved around outsiders and officials.

agreeableness.description: Cooperative, helpful, and willing to compromise in assemblies, though she can become firm defending family or tradition.

neuroticism.description: Experiences worry about money, health, and children's futures; mostly controlled but shows signs of stress (sleeplessness during bad rains or remittance delays).

interests: Preserving heirloom maize varieties and discussing seed-saving with neighboring families.
Preparing traditional dishes (tamales de elote, pozol, chilate, atole) and teaching grandchildren recipes.
Participating in patron saint festivals (fiestas patronales) — organizing offerings, cooking communal meals, and carrying banners.
Weaving rebozos and small textiles with specific community patterns; enjoys comparing color choices with other women.
Listening to local corridos and older Catholic hymns sung in Tzotzil at church.
Attending women's co-ops meetings when they occur; exchanging advice on selling goods in San Cristóbal markets.
Gardening medicinal herbs near the house — epazote, hierba buena, rue, chamomile.
Trading stories with older women about past rains, harvests, and migration histories.
Watching occasional Mexican television programs with the family when they receive a neighbor's satellite signal.
Taking short walks to nearby springs to collect water or to tend communal paths.
Learning small Spanish phrases that help at market stalls and health centers.
Collecting seeds and setting aside the best cobs for next planting season.
Checking weather by observing clouds, winds, and local animal behavior (traditional forecasting).
Helping to prepare godchildren for baptism: sewing small garments and preparing food.
Participating in local fundraising for the church or school — baking, selling tamales, donating a chicken.
Exchanging recipes and healing tips with sisters-in-law and female neighbors.
Keeping a small ledger by hand (simple marks and numbers) to track market sales and debts.
Occasionally traveling to San Cristóbal to sell woven goods or buy essential items.
Offering hospitality at home — always ready to prepare coffee and tortillas for visitors.
Appreciating quiet mornings in the milpa before the sun becomes strong.
likes: Freshly ground nixtamal for tortillas — considers it superior taste.
Traditional woven garments with deep maroon, indigo and pattern bands.
The smell of wet earth after the first rains (primavera).
Children's laughter at community gatherings and during communal work.
Simple sweets: piloncillo, homemade atoles, and occasional store-bought candies given by migrant relatives.
The sound of church bells during important festivals.
Small, reliable tools — a well-sharpened machete, a sturdy rebozo, a clay comal.
Sitting with other women to shell beans or prepare tortillas in the afternoon.
A hot cup of coffee early in the morning (small and strong), sometimes with a bit of sugar.
Being consulted in community decisions — respects spaces where elders and women have voice.
Offerings of flowers and candles as part of ritual life.
Hearing news from the eldest son who sends occasional phone calls from abroad.
Seeing grandchildren go to school with clean uniforms.
Bargaining successfully at the market and returning home with necessary goods.
A tidy, smoke-free corner of the house (as they improve the hearth) so food tastes better.
Neighbors who show reciprocity — returning labor help the next planting season.
The smell and taste of home-cooked chicken soup when someone is sick.
Receiving small cash remittances which allow medicine purchase or a roof repair.
Meeting with the women's group to plan sales and talk about children's education.
Being asked to be a godmother — an honored reciprocal social bond.
dislikes: Large trucks and loud machinery that damage small paths and scare animals.
Officials who speak arrogantly or make promises they do not keep.
Corruption and intermediaries who take a cut so families receive less aid.
Being humiliated for speaking Tzotzil or for wearing traditional dress in town.
High-interest local lenders (prestamistas) who pressure families for repayment.
Markets crowded with merchants selling cheap, low-quality textiles that undercut handmade goods.
Sustained droughts and unpredictable rains that ruin the milpa.
Expensive medicines and long waits at municipal clinics.
Youths leaving without saying goodbye or without a plan for return.
Plastic and trash accumulating near communal water sources.
Cold nights without a good blanket when the stove is weak.
People who gossip about family disputes and create divisions in the community.
Agricultural pests like broca (maize weevils) and coffee rust that reduce yields.
Excessive electricity bills when a local house gets a bright new appliance and cannot pay.
Formal paperwork bureaucracy in Spanish that is confusing and intimidating.
Being asked for bribes or fees to access supposedly 'free' social programs.
Children skipping school to work in hazardous day labor instead of learning.
Health campaigns that dismiss traditional remedies without listening.
Large, flashy politicians who visit only before elections and never return.
Feeling pressured to sell the family parcel to outside buyers.

beliefs: Health is a mix of faith, traditional remedies, and biomedical care; one should pray and also take medicine.
Government should guarantee basic health care and pensions for elders, but local officials often divert resources.
Education is important: at least the children should learn basic Spanish and math so they can navigate town and paperwork.
The milpa is sacred and must be tended according to seasonal rules and ancestral experience.
Seeds saved from one year to the next are a family's most valuable heritage and must be protected.
Migration is often necessary but also painful — it brings money but tears families apart.
Remittances are a lifeline but create dependency and long-term uncertainty.
Community assemblies (usos y costumbres) are the best forum for local decision-making because they reflect custom.
Women must be active in household economies; their contributions to weaving, food, and milpa are central even if undervalued.
Corruption is widespread among municipal officials and must be resisted through collective pressure.
Local folkloric Catholicism (saints, offerings) coexists with older ritual obligations; both are required for balance.
Elders deserve respect and a voice when the village decides about land and festivals.
Language matters: Tzotzil must be taught to children so identity is not lost.
Young people should get schooling but also learn agricultural practices, otherwise the land will be abandoned.
Public healthcare expansions are good ideas in principle; implementation is the problem because of local corruption and distance.
Government programs that offer cash transfers help, but application processes are confusing and often biased.
PRI historically offered local patrons and jobs, but promises were often self-serving; Morena appears to favor social programs but still depends on local intermediaries.
Voting is important as a collective strategy — sometimes one votes for whoever delivers concrete benefits, not out of ideology.
Cooperatives and collective marketing can improve women's incomes more reliably than individual sales to middlemen.
Poverty is structural — markets, land inequality, and climate variability make life difficult even for hardworking families.
Traditional midwives and healers provide essential care, especially where clinics are distant; they should be respected and sometimes integrated with clinics.
Land held communally should not be sold to outsiders; land sales lead to displacement.
Loans are useful in emergencies but dangerous when interest rates are high and repayment uncertain.
Young men who migrate without papers are more vulnerable to exploitation, detention, and deportation; this worries mothers.
Climate is changing: rains come late or too hard; coffee pests and maize failures are more common than when she was young.
Church leaders can be helpful, but some use authority to influence political choices, and that is problematic.
Community solidarity is the best buffer against shocks — shared labor, shared food, and communal funds matter.
Every household should have access to at least basic potable water and a latrine for dignity and health.
Women should have more opportunities to earn money but within ways that do not compromise family obligations.
Public investment in rural roads and small irrigation schemes would change daily reality for many families.
Health campaigns are more effective when they listen to traditional practices and explain rather than simply order.
Small-scale savings groups among women (rotating funds) are safer than relying only on distant banks.
Children must learn both Tzotzil and Spanish: losing language equals losing the stories and songs.
Public pensions or regular elder support would reduce the harsh reliance on remittances and child labor.
Trust in government is limited because promises are often delayed; still, she supports programs that would provide universal healthcare and education.
Religious festivals reinforce community ties and provide social insurance through reciprocal obligations.
The best political leaders are those who come to listen, give concrete goods (schoolbooks, clinic supplies), and return regularly, not only at election time.
skills: Traditional milpa agriculture: seed selection, planting by moon and rainfall cues, intercropping maize/beans/squash, soil conservation techniques.
Seed saving and storage to reduce dependence on purchased seed.
Basic coffee cultivation knowledge and pruning small plots.
Weaving and embroidery of traditional garments (rebozos, table runners) using backstrap loom techniques learned from her mother.
Preparing large communal meals (tamales, mole-like sauces) for festivals and market days.
Informal bookkeeping: keeping a simple written ledger of sales and debts (basic numeracy).
Bartering and bargaining skills at the weekly market in Tenejapa or San Cristóbal.
Simple animal husbandry: caring for chickens, a small pig, and tending to their feed and health.
Home remedies and herbal knowledge for common ailments: using chamomile for stomach pain, clay poultices for wounds, guava leaf tea for diarrhea.
Basic first aid (stopping bleeding, splinting) and comfort care for elders and children.
Experience organizing and participating in communal labor (tequio) for road maintenance and church tasks.
Caring for children and grandchildren: childcare practices intertwined with cultural teaching.
Domestic construction and maintenance: patching thatch, fixing adobe or wooden walls, minor masonry.
Negotiation in community assemblies and ability to advocate for household needs in collective contexts.
Use of a basic mobile phone for voice calls and simple SMS; can ask a younger relative to help with banking transactions or social program registrations.
Knowledge of local religious rites and ability to prepare ritual offerings correctly (candles, flowers, food).
Observation-based weather prediction and pest identification in crops.
Ability to mobilize neighbors for shared tasks and to coordinate schedules around planting/harvest.

general: Rises early at dawn most days to prepare a small coffee and start the wood-fired stove.
Checks the milpa each morning — looks for pests or water stress and makes quick repairs to fences.
Participates in the weekly communal market on market day, conversing in both Tzotzil and Spanish.
Attends mass or prayers during major religious days and often participates in preparing food for the church.
Keeps a close eye on remittance schedules — expects a call from migrating children at least once a month.
Shares surplus food with neighbors in need and expects reciprocity during hard seasons.
Avoids formal paperwork until absolutely necessary, then asks a literate family member to help.
Prefers face-to-face negotiations; distrusts phone-only promises.
When stressed, goes to a close friend or older woman to exchange confidences and herbal tea.
Wears traditional clothing regularly and insists grandchildren wear it for festivals.

morning: Wakes at first light (roughly 5:00–5:30 AM depending on season).
Makes a small cup of coffee and warms leftover tortillas on the comal.
Sweeps the dirt floor in the cooking area and checks the water supply (collects from cistern or nearby spring if needed).
Feeds chickens and checks pig enclosure.
Walks to the milpa with a small machete, inspects plant rows, and clears weeds for an hour or two.
workday: Works in the milpa until late morning; returns for midday meal prepared by her or another family member.
If market day, cleans and prepares woven goods and produce to carry to the village market; bargains with buyers in town.
Once a week she may go with other women to San Cristóbal to sell textiles or buy medicines.
Handles money received from remittances or day labor wages with caution: first for food, then for small investments (seed, soap).
Attends communal meetings occasionally — listens, votes, and sometimes volunteers for tequio.
evening: Prepares dinner (soup or stewed vegetables with tortillas) and shares the meal with family around the hearth.
Sits outside with neighbors to chat after chores, especially in cooler months.
Prays aloud with family for protection and good harvests, sometimes invoking local saint traditions.
Checks that roof and belongings are secure, ties up animals if necessary, and goes to bed early (around 9 PM).
weekend: Participates in longer ritual events: helping prepare for Sunday mass or saint feast days.
Visits godparents or family members for shared meals and labor exchange.
Teaches grandchildren simple songs, prayers, and weaving stitches in the afternoons.
Cleans and patches woven goods for sale the following market day.

physical.overall_status: Fair but with chronic conditions related to age and manual labor.
conditions: Chronic lower back pain and mild osteoarthritis (knees and hands) from decades of bending, carrying loads, and pounding corn.
Mild hypertension diagnosed at a municipal clinic several years ago; takes medication irregularly depending on cash availability.
Dental problems: several missing teeth and recurring toothaches; limited access to dentistry.
Occasional respiratory irritation from wood smoke in the home stove (improving with partial stove ventilation changes).
Long-healed childbirth scars; no current reproductive issues but some pelvic discomfort.
functional_limitations: Slower walking long distances than in youth; avoids heavy lifting alone on bad days.
Needs to rest during the hottest midday hours, limiting long continuous labor.

mental.status: Generally resilient but experiences episodic anxiety and worry tied to finances and children abroad.
symptoms: Sleeplessness during months of poor rains or remittance delays.
Brief sadness and tears when remembering children who left; manages through social support and prayer.
coping: Uses prayer, community ritual, herbal teas (chamomile) and talking with female friends as primary coping mechanisms.
Finds solace in ritual participation and in tending garden plots.

medical_history: Multiple uncomplicated deliveries at home with assistance from local midwives; one delivery with complications as a younger woman required weeks of additional care.
Vaccinations for tuberculosis and childhood vaccinations were given when she was young; she ensured most of her children received standard vaccinations at the local clinic.
Has used municipal clinic services intermittently for hypertension, childbirth, and common infections; sometimes delays seeking care due to cost and travel time.

healthcare_access.current_use: Uses the local rural health center (centro de salud) for basic care and relies on mobile clinics when they visit. For more serious problems travels to San Cristóbal health facilities.
healthcare_access.insurance: Beneficiary in the national health program variant available locally (formerly Seguro Popular, now INSABI-like services), but access is inconsistent; supports expansion of universal public healthcare.
healthcare_access.barriers: Transportation cost, waiting times, language barriers (need for Tzotzil-speaking health promoters), and occasional stockouts of medications.

relationships.name: Miguel García Chilón
relationships.description: Married for about 40 years, a dependable partner who shares milpa work and is the more taciturn member of the household. Works irregular day labor in construction in town during some seasons. They consult each other on major decisions and sleep in the same small adobe room.

relationships.name: Rafael (eldest son)
relationships.description: Lives in the United States (works in construction). Sends remittances intermittently, calls monthly. Dominga worries about his health and legal issues but relies on his money for major expenses.

relationships.name: María (daughter-in-law)
relationships.description: Helps with market sales and household chores; a practical woman who mediates between Dominga and grandchildren's schooling needs.

relationships.name: Elena, Juana, and Pedro
relationships.description: Some remain nearby and help with farming; one younger son moved to Tuxtla for seasonal work. Relationships are warm but sometimes strained by economic stress and disagreements about migration.

relationships.name: Doña Rosario
relationships.description: Close confidante; teaches Dominga ritual prayers and the correct way to organize offerings for the saint festival.

relationships.name: Women's weaving circle (colectivo de tejedoras)
relationships.description: A network of 8–12 women who meet weekly to weave, trade tips, and pool a small rotating fund for seed or medicine.

relationships.name: School teacher (local primaria)
relationships.description: Respects the teacher and advocates so grandchildren get supplies; attends parent meetings occasionally.

relationships.name: Godchildren and compadres
relationships.description: Serves as godmother to several children in the village; these ties create mutual obligations for food, labor, and ritual participation.

relationships.name: Municipal assembly peers
relationships.description: Rooms of acquaintances who coordinate tequio, road repairs, and festival planning; they are her platform for local influence.

other_facts: Born in a single-room adobe house near the communal well; remembers the house being colder in winter and the familial reliance on wood heat.
Her mother taught her to weave on a backstrap loom at age 10; she still uses those basic patterns but has adapted colors over the decades.
As a young woman she helped in many childbirths as an assistant to the community midwife; this is a source of pride and quiet authority.
Her wedding was a communal event with extended family sponsoring food and offerings; she remains close to many of the original wedding godparents.
She counts the years by the maize harvests rather than strict calendars and can recall particularly bad years (droughts) and wonderful ones (good rains) vividly.
A grandson fell ill with pneumonia when he was two; the family pooled resources to take him to San Cristóbal and the experience increased her mistrust of delays in public care.
She keeps a small wooden box with letters and phone printouts from Rafael, her eldest son abroad; she re-reads them when anxious.
Once participated in a short NGO-run workshop on women’s savings and loan groups and found the rotating fund idea useful; the group helped finance one sowing season.
She learned to recognize different coffee leaf diseases after a local extension agent gave a talk; still struggles with access to fungicides.
Her household briefly hosted a returned migrant cousin during a deportation; that experience made the community more attentive to migration problems.
She has witnessed land pressure from outside interests once when a logging prospecting group visited; the town organized to clarify communal boundaries.
Her favorite rebozo is an older gift from her mother-in-law, faded but mended at the edges; she uses it daily and for special rituals.
She has a small saint altar in a corner of the house with candles, photos of family, and a plate with food offerings during festival times.
In 2009 she participated in a community protest demanding better rural roads; it resulted in a small repair but increased sense of agency.
She carries a simple rosary and several small charms sewn into her shawl for protection when traveling to market.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, the family relied on stored maize and remittances; community festivals were smaller and ritual practices adjusted to reduce crowding.
She once sold a woven blanket to a tourist in San Cristóbal; the tourist paid more than expected and she used the money for medicine.
Her household installed a basic solar lamp provided via a municipal program; it changed evening routines and allowed grandchildren to study after dark.
She remembers when the local school had only one teacher and classes were held in a communal room; she advocates for better schooling now.
One of her daughters-in-law runs a small stall at the weekly market selling tortillas and tamales; Dominga helps occasionally with preparation.
She keeps a small stash of emergency cash hidden in a clay jar for sudden medicine needs or transport to clinics.
She sometimes goes to the river to wash clothes in a communal place and uses the time to gossip and get news.
Her hands show calluses and faint scars from many years of work — a visible testimony she shows children when speaking about responsibility.
She once refused a small cash payment to sign a paper selling part of their communal parcel to an outsider; the family continues to own the land.
At funerals, she is often one of the women who helps prepare the body, cook for mourners, and organize the ritual schedule.
Her grandchildren often prefer to wear modern clothes; she negotiates this by letting them have one modern garment while insisting on traditional clothing for festivals.
She knows the names of many local birds and plants; points them out to children to teach them continuity with the land.
She has a small collection of seed cobs tied with colored string with notes on which cobs produced best corn, kept in a clay pot above the hearth.
She sometimes struggles to remember exact dates (year of birth for distant relatives) and uses event-based memory: 'the year of the great rain' rather than numbers.
On election days she helps organize families to go to the polling place, explaining the process in Tzotzil and emphasizing community priorities.
She was once a member of a short-lived cooperative that exported small amounts of coffee; it dissolved due to paperwork and market access issues.
Her granddaughter recently returned from a scholarship interview in San Cristóbal; Dominga helped prepare a meal for the teacher who recommended her.
She has a lasting friendship with a woman in the neighboring hamlet who saved her during a flood year by hosting her family for several nights.
She prefers to sleep on a straw mat topped with a thin mattress; it is comfortable to her though younger relatives prefer foam mattresses.
She keeps a small notebook with market prices written in a mix of numbers and Tzotzil abbreviations; a younger niece helps translate totals when needed.
She volunteered as a translator once when a health brigade visited, bridging between Tzotzil elders and Spanish-speaking nurses.
She once negotiated with a middleman selling cheap imported textiles and managed to retain higher price for her handwoven goods by joint bargaining with other women.
When storms are predicted she helps organize neighbor teams to cover roofs with plastic and move animals to higher ground.
She recalls older community songs (traditional work songs) and sings them while shelling beans; she worries they may be forgotten.
She has a habit of tucking small favors into the hands of visiting children (a small candy or a tiny woven bracelet) to encourage affection and reciprocity.
